abstract.p: William R Andersen letter on Harold Bloom's June 4 article on e-books holds there are myriad ways to deliver writer's art and some have enormous advantage over others

block.p: Harold Bloom's disappointment with electronic text readers was predictable. If you take a fellow who has so resisted technology that he doesn't use a keyboard and then give him a very limited electronic reader which doesn't allow one to adjust line length or font size (and which requires a button push to ''turn'' a page) and then give him a book he really doesn't like, it is not surprising that he will be disappointed.

Harold Bloom's disappointment with electronic text readers was predictable. If you take a fellow who has so resisted technology that he doesn't use a keyboard and then give him a very limited electronic reader which doesn't allow one to adjust line length or font size (and which requires a button push to ''turn'' a page) and then give him a book he really doesn't like, it is not surprising that he will be disappointed.

As with books recorded on tape, books serialized in newspapers or books read by grandmothers, there are many ways of delivering a writer's art, and depending on the circumstances, some have enormous advantages over others. The next time you fly, get a decent reader, put into it several of your technical manuals, a novel or two, Daniel J. Boorstin's recent history of thought, a volume of poetry and The New York Times Magazine -- all of which fit into a little leather case in a corner of your briefcase. You'll love the flight.
